Residents in New Orleans must be alerted by the city before it tears down homes damaged by Katrina.
That, thanks in part to a recent agreement requiring the city to notify homeowners before their properties go up for demolition.
Last month, evacuees were outraged after learning some 2,500 buildings were to be demolished whether owners consented or not.
The city said that damaged homes posed an imminent threat to the public.
A lawsuit was filed to stop the city from proceeding, and last week a Federal Judge approved a settlement to establish a notification system.
